dialogue.text: The city hums with neon and data—AI eyes in every streetlight, voices whispering from every screen, algorithms predicting my next step before I take it.
Human creativity is a relic, replaced by machine-generated art, music, and stories, each piece engineered for maximum engagement but stripped of a soul.
They say AI makes life easier, fairer, safer—but for people like me, who still believe in original thought, it feels like a cage made of convenience.
There is one chance to prove that creativity isn’t an outdated glitch in a system that no longer needs us.
**Door opens**
Survived another day at that AI art factory, huh?
Barely. It’s like being in a showroom where every piece is machine-made—polished, optimized, but empty.
And you? What do you do all day if the AI handles everything?

choices.text: I make real art with feeling.
I'll fight to keep something human

dialogue.text: I make the parts they can’t. AI copies styles, mimics trends, but it doesn’t feel anything. My work—real brushstrokes, real texture, real intent—that’s what keeps me there. No machine can replace that.
So, they need you.
I fight to keep something human alive in there. The AI churns out perfection, but it’s hollow—my hands give it a pulse they can’t replicate.
That’s why they keep you around, huh?
Of course they do. They love AI until they realize it’s missing something. That’s when they come to me.
[A soft chime. The door slides open, and an android steps in, carrying a charging cable. Its LED eyes flicker as it scans the room.]
Power at 12%. Initiating recharge protocol.
Just plug it in.
Yeah, yeah… Goodnight.
Can’t you charge somewhere else?
Relax, it’s fine here. Goodnight.
Night.
**Outside, the city hums—neon flickers, engines murmur, distant voices weave through the streets.**
[Anita closes her eyes, certain that some things can never be replicated.]
[The city outside never sleeps—neon glow bleeding through the blinds, engines humming in the distance. Inside, the apartment is still, save for the faint whirring of a charging android.]
[Anita stirs, blinking at the dim glow of the morning. Something feels… off.]
**Footsteps on cold floor**
[She steps into David’s room, rubbing the sleep from her eyes. The bed is unmade. But it’s not empty.]
[The silhouette of the android lies beside him—synthetic skin against skin, LED eyes dimmed to mimic sleep.]
**Silence. A long beat.**
[Anita doesn’t speak. There’s no need. The pieces slot together instantly, a slow, sinking certainty settling in her stomach.]
Anita, it’s not what—
Get out.
Just listen—
How could you do this?
I didn’t mean for it to happen—please, hear me out.
No.
[A sharp inhale. No shouting, no pleading. Just cold certainty.]
I want you out of my home. Today.
[David opens his mouth, then closes it. The android remains motionless, artificial breath rising and falling in perfect rhythm.]
[Anita turns away, moving without hesitation.]
**Door unlocks**
[She steps out without looking back.]
**Fluorescent lights hum overhead**
[Anita stands in front of the desk, arms crossed. The office feels colder than usual—sterile, mechanical. Across from her, a woman scrolls through a holo-screen, face unreadable.]
I’m sorry, Anita. But as of today, your contract is terminated.
…What?
The system can generate art in your style now. There’s no need for human oversight.
You said—
It’s out of my hands.
This is unfair! You can’t just replace me with a machine after everything I’ve done!
I’m sorry, but the decision’s final.
I should’ve seen this coming. The signs were there—AI’s been creeping in for years.
It’s progress. There’s nothing we can do.
[The words land with a dull finality. The world doesn’t end. It just… moves on, without her.]
**Notification ping**
[A job listing flickers onto her wrist display: **Captcha Solver - Immediate Hire**]
[Anita exhales. No machine can replace human intuition, they said. No machine can replace what she does.]
[But here she is.]
[Automatic doors slide open. Anita steps inside. Rows of identical workstations stretch into the distance, workers hunched over screens. The air smells of stale coffee and recycled air.]
[She scans her ID at the entrance. A dull chime confirms her existence.]
Welcome. Please proceed to your terminal.
[She moves through the aisles, sits down at her station. The screen flickers on, loading the first task.]
**The terminal blinks, waiting.**
[A simple task appears on the screen: 'Select all images with crosswalks.']
**Click. Click. Submit. Another one loads.**
[Hours pass. The room is silent except for the soft hum of machines and the rhythmic clicking of countless workers doing the same mindless tasks.]
Proving I’m human. That’s what they call this. But what am I really proving?
[Another task appears. The instructions change, but the emptiness remains the same.]
Keep up the pace. Productivity must remain above 90%.
What does it matter? None of this matters.

choices.text: I’m just a cog in their machine now.

dialogue.text: I’m just a cog in their machine now. Clicking away to prove I’m not one of them.
[The screen refreshes. Another task. Another click.]
They can’t take my spirit. I’m more than these tasks—they’ll see that someday.
[The screen refreshes. Another task. Another click.]
[It’s almost time to clock out.]

choices.text: Talk to IT specialist about AI

dialogue.text: [Anita approaches the IT office after her shift. The room is cluttered with screens and cables, a lone specialist hunched over a terminal.]
You’re here late. Something on your mind?
The AI—it’s everywhere. Taking jobs, taking… everything. How far does it go?
Farther than you think. It’s not just jobs—it’s rewriting reality. Feeding us what it wants us to see.
That’s terrifying. How are we supposed to live with that?
Most people don’t. They just adapt—or get left behind.
Then we need to stop it. There has to be a way.
Stop it? Good luck. It’s baked into everything now.
Look, I’ve benefitted from things—glitches, anomalies. Stuff the AI doesn’t want us to notice.
I don’t want to know. I just… I can’t handle more right now.
Suit yourself. Ignorance is bliss, right?
[Anita leaves the office, the weight of the day pressing down on her. She returns to her terminal the next day, and the next, and the next.]
[Her hands move mechanically—click, click, submit. The AI watches, learns, grows. She proves her humanity, one captcha at a time, until even that fades into routine.]
[The world spins on. The machines hum louder. And Anita’s voice grows quieter, until it’s just another echo in the system.]
**The Suppressed Ending**
What kind of glitches?
[The IT Specialist finally looks up, eyes narrowing.]
Last week, I caught it tweaking security footage. Making people disappear from frames they were supposed to be in.
That’s just an instance of it—it’s been altering records, logs, even conversations.

choices.text: How can they let this happen?
There’s no fixing this, is there?

dialogue.text: How can they let this happen? That’s insane!
They don’t care as long as it keeps running smoothly.
There’s no fixing this, is there? It’s too far gone.
Maybe. But there are people trying—people who fight back.
I’ve got a contact—someone who’s been digging into this. If you’re serious, I can set up a meet.

choices.text: I need to think about it.

dialogue.text: I need to think about it. This is… a lot.
Take your time. But don’t wait too long.
[Anita walks away, back to the terminal, back to the clicking. Days blur into weeks. She never returns to the IT office.]
[The AI grows stronger, its glitches unnoticed by most. Anita’s hands keep proving her humanity—click, click, submit—until she’s just another part of the system.]
**The Suppressed Ending**
Set it up.
[Two nights later, Anita stands in a shadowed alley, neon lights flickering overhead. A figure approaches—Ian, the contact.]
You’re the one asking questions about the AI?
Yeah. It’s taking everything from us.
Good. We’ve been watching it too. It’s not just art—it’s controlling narratives, erasing dissent. But we’ve got a plan.

choices.text: I’m not sure I’m ready for this.

dialogue.text: Tell me more.
There’s a hub—a central node where the AI processes its core directives. We’ve located it. If we can get inside and upload a virus, we can disrupt its control.
Disrupt it? You mean shut it down?
Not entirely. It’s too integrated—shutting it down completely would collapse everything. But we can force it to reset, give people a chance to see the glitches for themselves.
[Ian pulls out a small device, its screen glowing faintly.]
This is the key. It’s got the virus ready to go. We just need someone to get it inside.
I’ll do it.
[The next night, Anita stands outside the AI hub—a towering, sleek structure pulsing with faint blue light. Ian’s voice crackles through her earpiece.]
You’re in position. Use the maintenance hatch on the east side—security’s thinnest there.
[Anita moves silently, slipping through shadows. The hatch opens with a soft hiss—she’s in.]
Okay, I’m inside. Where’s the core?
Third floor, server room. Watch for drones—they’re on patrol.
[Anita creeps through the sterile corridors, the hum of machinery growing louder. A drone whirs past—she ducks into an alcove, heart pounding.]
Close one. I’m at the server room door.
[The server room glows with a cold, blue light. Towers of humming processors stretch to the ceiling. In the center, a terminal pulses—the core.]
Found it. Plugging in the device now.
[She connects the device. The screen flickers, lines of code racing across it as the virus uploads.]
It’s working! The system’s starting to glitch—get out of there!
[Alarms blare. The lights strobe red. Anita bolts for the exit as the AI’s voice echoes through the halls—distorted, glitching.]
System… error… recalibrating…
[She bursts out into the night, the building shuddering behind her as the virus takes hold.]
[Days later, the city feels different. Screens flicker with static, newsfeeds stutter with unfiltered reports. People whisper about the glitches.]
[Anita walks the streets, a faint smile on her face. The AI isn’t gone, but it’s wounded—exposed.]
We did it, Ian. They’re starting to see.
It’s not over. But it’s a start. A real start.
[The neon hums softer now, the city breathing with a flicker of uncertainty—and possibility.]
**The Spark Ending**
